text: welcome in Venice this is the city
without cars
[Music]
situated on a hundred and eighteen small
islands in northeastern Italy Venice is
a unique place to say the least there
are so many wonderful sights to see take
a walk over the rialto bridge be stunned
by the Grand Canal take a lap around San
Marco Square and get lost
in the narrow side streets I'm sure and
I can touch both sides of my hands
instead of having roads to connect the
city there are a hundred and seventeen
canals which are linked by over 400
bridges no vehicles are allowed in the
main parts of Venice we had to park our
car two miles away and take a 40-minute
water bus in so we just hopped on a
water bus to take us to San Marco square
the only way to get around the city is
by foot or by boat everything else that
involves daily life is transported on
boats through the canals if someone
needs medical attention
a water ambulance will pick them up if
someone wants to do laundry a laundry
boat will come to the rescue and then
you have the iconic gondolas which are
made entirely of wood taking a ride on
one is really expensive like a hundred
and twenty bucks for 40 minutes but it's
absolutely worth it for an experience
that you can only get in Venice what's
up everyone we are riding on the famous
gondola ride in Venice cost 100 euros
but who cares it's worth it and to be
honest it's the most peaceful way to see
the city far away from the touristy
streets how many years are you abandoned
over here there's thirty Wow
crazy yes so if you ask me Venice is one
of the most unique cities in the world
and it was great to be back here again
alright we're wrapping up our day here
in Venice we're heading out and all
honesty it's a great place to see for a
couple hours but there are literally so
many tours that it gets a little bit
annoying so kind of excited to get out
of here I'll definitely be back here
some time in my life but as for now we
are heading to Vania
